And within that, let's say, we have approximately 3 to 4 percentage points of rating migration. So, linked to Basel III effect, or in terms of volume is something, which is more in the mid-single-digit figure, and in mind that France grew by something like 4. We're actually above mid-single in retail outside France and Financial Services will be the mid-singles for this year in big businesses.
Now, let me just comment on – first of all, I am-my view is – my view on that emerging markets will resume growing more quickly than developed countries.

And in emerging markets, of course, you have very different situations. I think it's difficult to comment in situations like, for example, countries like in Hungary or Ukraine where you have already a crisis, which can be related to political environment, as well as macroeconomic picture, with deficit, external deficits, more or less weaker banking system. Countries which, like in Russia, at the end of the day with the macroeconomic picture, will be very much related to the oil of price. Countries, which in Africa for example, and Mediterranean basin, will of course, have lower growth, but have the benefit of the relatively benign impact of the toxic asset liquidity issues et cetera. So, the picture is very mixed.

It is clear in my view that we can grow. It remains growth story in the long term. We are not in a hurry, if I may, say. And in these markets, strong banks like our subsidiaries will be able to make the difference in a much easier way than in developed countries where competition will be very tough and in countries where again, we expect relatively sluggish growth going forward, with the need to absorb not only the immediate shock of the crisis, but also the fact that there are huge deficits in imports, significant public debts, which will have to be sorted out. And certain structural ills like in the US where probably consumer spending cannot just rely on effectively over indebtedness going forward, but a slightly different model.

So, at this stage let me say that first of all, the priority for the next six months is to monitor the crisis. I personally consider that there might be still volatility, bad news, nervousness. And I think it's important just to demonstrate that we can fare properly through this period. Then I think we will be focus predominantly in the same regions, Central, Eastern Europe, Mediterranean basin. Asia is again, also a region of interest. We've made an investment in Vietnam in August 2008. We carry on developing in China, but I will say overall it is a longer term perspective. Perhaps...
I don't have the breakdown of the numbers you've been asking in the combinations. I'd like to come back to you. Pass you on to Didier -
Didier?

I have not again, such detail, but just in Russia to mention that we have the €2 billion of withstanding CIB too and the rest is limited, because the bulk of the lending to corporate is done through the local subsidiaries. I think maybe commercial bank has certain exposure. managed as part of the synergies within the Group by CIB. But that it's also a very limited portion of CIB loan book, which is exposed to this segment.
Séverin, on the cost cutting exercise?

As Didier mentioned we have two set of initiative. We have what we call structural efficiency plan, which is long-term initiative to improve the productivity of different properties within the Bank, and which will deliver this 1 billion we mentioned one year ago after the fourth Q of year. And this will be implemented in fact, in 2010. Of course, the impact would be higher after probably start of structural gains.

And we have launched in 2008 a second set of initiative, which is really the cost cutting initiatives and which are changing our consumption policies, in fact, for traveling, for anything like that including, for IT spending also.
So your question in term of divisional split of this gain is we have three – in the structural part of our action, which will deliver this one billion next year, we have three type of initiatives.

We have what you call mutualizations part. And the main part of that is IT infrastructure mutualization. This will gain – the gain will be split over or rather according to the IT intensity of each business not and it's because of all the IT spending of the company. So, you will see that it is more benefiting to the retail, which is high intensive in France mainly speaking and in CIB, which we have also a high intensity in term of IT today.
The second type of initiative is process industrialization, what we call is Lean approach in terms of profit. And this would benefit mainly to CIB and to Jean-Claude's division.

And the third is what we call sourcing optimization, which mean call to off-shoring capability and to designing our contracting capability. Today we have 10,000 people working for us as contractors. So, we are really asking our contractors to relocate this capability that we've got. So, all in all, really the interest in 1 billion plus is a cost cutting approach. There is – it will be probably fair to say that the proportion of general spending of each division will benefit in the same average, all in all. You have a total spending at the Group level of 16 billion and you will have to allocate this 1 billion further cost cutting initiative regarding the portion of each division.
Anymore question in the room or online? Online? Okay.
We have the question online from Mr. Jean-Pierre from Nomura. Please go ahead, sir.

Hi. I realize it's late. Let me limit it just to one question and one clarification. The question is on French Retail and I just wondered how much of the Q4 increase in provisions was the start of a deteriorating trend and how much was really a bit of year-end housekeeping. So, we might see that absolute number come down a little in the first part of '09? The clarification is just around the numbers that you gave us for the stress test. I just wanted to check those were percentages of Basel I risk weighted assets. Thanks.

Okay. On the French Retail there's effectively always a seasonality factor, but I would say the bulk of the increase is more related to the crisis and the SME-the impact on the SMEs. It is difficult to predict the cost of risk. So, I would not be that surprised to have in the first quarter something more or less the same magnitude, if you wish.

Regarding effective the basis points we mentioned it's in terms of risk weighted assets in Basel I. We will, going forward, communicate progressively in percentage of exposure at defaults but we don't want to disturb you too much at this stage. So, effectively we keep the same measurement tool.
Okay. Thank you.
We have a question online from Mr. Eric Vanpoucke with Oppenheim. Please go ahead, sir.

Hi, just going through quickly, a couple of questions. The first one, do you intend to implement the impairment test on your subsidiaries on a quarterly basis or are you going to do it only on a yearly basis? Secondly, should we expect some one-off cost, for instance, for redundancy plans in 2009? And can you just give us some flavor regarding value at risk in Q4? And what would you expect for the beginning of 2009? Thank you.
Regarding the first question on the impairment of the goodwill, we review that on a quarterly basis.

Regarding the restructuring cost, yes, we might have some restructuring costs in certain businesses. The magnitude should be relatively limited. Thirdly, on the value at risk, well, you have the figures. Let me just remind you that we have historical scenarios and so, clearly, we had to input in the calculation, the scenarios of the fourth quarter. We use a 99% methodology. It means that basically, we retain the average between the second and third largest loss in the last 250 scenarios. And we will keep these scenarios, these stress scenarios for basically one year. The positions are very low basically, and that's why also probably with limited risk. But let's say, we can expect a level of VAR probably of that kind of magnitude for certain period of time, before the scenarios disappear.
Any more questions?
We have a follow-up question from Guillaume Tiberghien from Credit Suisse. Please go ahead, sir.

Sorry, the question relates to the AFS reserves again, in the shareholder equity. If I look at your financial statements in June, you had negative 152 million for a change in fair value of assets available for sale. And in the statement of shareholder equity this time, the number has gone from minus 152 to minus 2.1 billion. And I am not actually sure that I understand what has happened to explain the 2 billion difference. Thank you.
So you mentioned in June – between June and the end of the year?
Yes.

I've got the movement between end of September and end of December. But let's see, the figure was-because I don't have the detail in the whole series, but the figure was on the AFS a positive plus 1.2 at the end of '07, a negative of minus 1.1 at the end of September and then negative, as I said, earlier, of minus 2.1 at the end of December. And so there is a change that we see is essentially linked to the interest movements that we've seen during the quarter, which has triggered some negative mark-to-market in the OCI, that's it. But as I said, this is offset by the plus €1 billion on the cash coverage and on the deferred tax assets. The mark-to-market on the available for sale is essentially on fixed income product, I would say. Because on the equity side, from top of my mind, it is something like minus 100. And on the shareholding portfolio, we are matching the detail of the press release, we have a slide showing capital gain of something like 30 to €40 million.
With that, Guillaume, if you have – you want to ask more questions on that, you can go to our IR department.
Okay.
Okay?
Thank you.
No more questions in the room? Okay, well thank you very much for your attention. Good evening.
